title: Emmanuel Macron: 'Now is the time for the EU to launch a joint borrowing capacity, through eurobonds'
subhed: Two days ahead of a meeting of European Union heads of state and government in Brussels, the French president calls on the 27 member states, in an interview with Le Monde and several other European newspapers, to make joint investments in protecting the environment, as well as in artificial intelligence and quantum technology, to avoid falling behind.
byline: Interview by Virginie Malingre (Brussels, Europe bureau)

title: Epstein files unveil sex offender's ties with Kremlin insiders
US remains top export market for French wines and spirits, despite 21% drop
Macron nominates budget minister as top government auditor
subhed: Amélie de Montchalin, a close ally of the president, will become the first woman to head France's Court of Auditors. She will be evaluating many policies she herself helped implement.
byline: By Denis Cosnard and Bastien Scordia

title: Israel's retention of Palestinian bodies: A silent 'hostage-taking'
subhed: More than 670 bodies of West Bank residents have been confiscated by Israel for years, in violation of international law. Their families hope that the return of all the bodies of Israelis held in Gaza by Hamas will prompt the Israeli authorities to soften their stance.
byline: By Luc Bronner (Qarawat Bani Hassan (West Bank), special correspondent)

title: New York's 'bodega boys,' the Yemeni shopkeepers caught in Trump's immigration crackdown
subhed: The Trump administration imposed a new entry ban in June 2025 targeting 12 countries, including Yemen. The move has put at risk a community deeply rooted in the local economy: the 'bodega boys,' mostly Yemeni shopkeepers who run corner grocery stores throughout New York.

title: How the Epstein scandal brought down Jack Lang: 'Everyone knew he never paid for anything'
subhed: The emblematic minister from President François Mitterrand's era was forced to step down as president of the Arab World Institute in Paris. Former allies and rivals have begun to speak out about a man who used his influence and network to maintain a lavish lifestyle.

title: France's municipal elections at risk of foreign interference
French central bank governor voices concern over slow pace of EU reforms as he steps down
byline: By Eric Albert and Béatrice Madeline

title: Rugby legend Serge Blanco launches bid to become Biarritz mayor
Iran: Videos show live ammunition used in crackdown

Lawyers of Le Pen allies condemn lower court's 'caricature of justice' in appeal's closing argument

Jack Lang, a central node in France-Morocco power networks
Jean-Luc Mélenchon fumes after party is labeled 'far-left' by government
Epstein accomplice Maxwell refuses to answer questions from US House panel
Gucci owner Kering sees net profit plunge, but sales stabilize
How Donald Trump is rewriting US history
subhed: As the country marks its 250th anniversary this year, the American president, who returned to the White House on January 20, 2025, has worked to shape a revised historical narrative, revealing signs of megalomania.

title: 2026 Olympics: 'In Russia, even an amateur athlete can become an agent of influence'
subhed: The Milan-Cortina Olympic Games mark a new stage in the reintegration of Russian athletes into international competitions. The momentum has been fueled by Moscow's efforts to use sports as an instrument of power, explains researcher Lukas Aubin in an interview with Le Monde.

title: Mayor and mother: The young women changing France's local councils
subhed: Only 41 women under the age of 30 were elected as mayors in 2020, out of France's 34,885 mayors. Here are the stories of several women who have balanced their careers, motherhood and first terms in office in a political scene often dominated by older men.

title: Jimmy Lai, a symbol of the end of freedom in Hong Kong

The challenge of action for France's fragile and constrained government
